text: <@U018DRGAC5S> I don’t know much about Houyhnhnm politics, but I suspect they are as much subject to Conway’s law as we are. So their software architecture should reflect the architecture of the social organization of their programmers. which is why I’d love to know more about the latter.

text: Right, if we restrict the topic to how *programmers* are organized, that would be a more publishable topic on the blog...

text: Actually, you remind me I one wrote a document about how to choose programming languages with the long term in mind, that I need to rewrite and publish.

elements.text: Actually, you remind me I one wrote a document about how to choose programming languages with the long term in mind, that I need to rewrite and publish.

text: Please do! It's a question I get asked frequently when I talk about computational reproducibility (and that is rather often nowadays). I tend to reply with the principle-whose-name-I-always-forget that says that the expected future duration of an event is equal to its duration so far. (This is a maximum likelihood argument based on an uninformed prior, so it's not valid of you have more specific information.) So... if you want your code to be usable for twenty years or more (not uncommon in scientific computing), consider C, Fortran, Java, or Common Lisp. But I am not really happy with that answer.

I tend to reply with the principle-whose-name-I-always-forget that says that the expected future duration of an event is equal to its duration so far. So... if you want your code to be usable for twenty years or more (not uncommon in scientific computing), consider C, Fortran, Java, or Common Lisp. But I am not really happy with that answer.

text: A search on duckduckgo reveals this is called the Lindy Effect <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindy_effect>

elements.text: A search on duckduckgo reveals this is called the Lindy Effect

text:
But bear in mind that the question is not just did it survive, but how did it survive?

FORTRAN will survive 63 more years, becoming more and more of niche for physicists and legacy numerical recipes.

We can expect Lisp to survive 62 more years, but Common Lisp in particular to only survive 26 years during which its standard will never see an update. Rather it will continue to see tens of new dialects each with a small following, some to survive by being embedded in successful applications such as Emacs.

We can expect COBOL to survive 61 more years, and during those 61 years, to grow into more of a Lovecraftian horror grafted onto a primitive ancient beast.

C shall survive only 48 more years, its standard being updated every decade or so, becoming ever more of a niche, with ever more subtle undefined behaviors causing programmers to break everything in the name of ever more dubious optimizations with diminishing returns.

Java has only 25 years of life in it. First they said it was good for app-lets. Then they recoiled and said it was good for serv-lets. Eventually, they will realize it's only good for toy-lets, as its towering cesspool of engineered mediocrity is made obsolete by Artificial Mediocrity.
